elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: INT. TARDIS — ADRIC’S ROOM
(READING) ‘Learn well the old tales, for they bear the stuff of truth. Look to the ones who shun the day. Avoid those with the burning eyes and the thirst-’
What are you reading?
FX: ADRIC SHUTS BOOK.
On my planet, Tegan, it’s considered very rude to just walk into somebody’s room without asking permission.
Funny how you care so much about good manners when it inconveniences you. What’s the book?
Dracoola.
It’s pronounced Dracula. Didn’t have you down as a horror fan, Adric — I thought you’d have your nose in a maths book.
I’ve read all the ones in the TARDIS library. And I thought this might be useful.
It’s just a story, how could it possibly be useful?
It seems to me, it’s best to be prepared in case we run into any more vampires.
‘Any more?’

Mm. We met three of them in E-Space, and the Doctor tells me there are vampire legends on almost every inhabited planet in this Universe — the Reavers of Actinon [acty-non], the NASA experiments of the 1970s, the fabled lost spaceship—
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 3
You think I can’t tell when you’re having me on.
I am definitely not ‘having you on’. I don’t think. Is that an Australian thing?
It’s an Earth thing. It means you’re pulling my leg.
And ‘pulling your leg’ means...?
I’m not going to teach you the meanings of words and phrases, Adric, you already speak English.
No, you speak Alzarian. What do you want, Tegan? I’m very busy.
That’s a laugh. I’ve never seen anyone so bored in their life. That’s the trouble with clever-clogs like you — you can’t stop fidgeting.
What part of that sentence am I supposed to understand?
Look, I’ve given up on the Doctor. He’s always promising to take me back to Heathrow, and we never get there!
I can’t understand why you’re so keen to get back to vessels that can only go up and down, when you’re on a craft that can travel through the entire infinity of the universe.
Well, that’s only one of the differences between me and you. The other is that you know how to fly the TARDIS.
Me?
You took it to Castrovalva, didn’t you?
In a manner of speaking. I wasn’t exactly myself at the time.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 4
Well, you are now. The Master’s dead, the Doctor’s off making repairs to who-knows-what — now’s the chance to show off your skills.
It would be nice to show that I can pilot the TARDIS when I’m not under anyone else’s control. I’ve already done plenty of simulations.
Yeah, don’t remind me of anything that might make me change my mind. Just get me to the right place in the right year.
Heathrow, 1981?
Do you reckon you can do it?
Of course I can do it! But the Doctor would be furious with me!
He’s always furious with you.
He didn’t used to be. Things were different when-
When it was just you and him? Well, get me home, and there’11l be one less of us. You’d like that, wouldn’t you?
You’re sure the Doctor’s not in the control room?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 2: INT. TARDIS — CORRIDOR
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA WALK UP.
Two to the right. That’s the one.
So how do you get to the circuits?
(PUSHING ROUNDEL) Just put some pressure on the centre of the roundel, then (TWISTING ROUNDEL) .. give it a good twist to the
left! (LIFTING OFF ROUNDEL) There! Could you take that for me?
Where...?
Just leave it by your feet for now.
FX: SHE PLACES ROUNDEL ON FLOOR AS DOCTOR PULLS AT WIRING.

You know, I’ve been meaning to get around to these repairs for centuries. That’s the problem with time travel, Nyssa — there’s always a fresh distraction. Some day, I’d like to park the TARDIS in the vortex for a decade or so, get a few odd jobs done, then catch up on my reading. I hear very good things about Christopher Marlowe. And P.G. Wodehouse.
So once these circuits are fixed, we’ll have the Zero Room back?
Well, it’1ll grow back on its own eventually, but the process would be a lot more reliable if the TARDIS had a proper stabiliser. I was warned about it when I first, er, procured her.
By “procured”, you mean “stole”.

Not exactly. If I hadn’t have taken her, she might have been consigned to some pocket dimension, left to waste away. Terrible the way Gallifreyan society treats its old age pensioners. But there’s plenty of life left in the old girl yet.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 6
Yesterday, you called her a “flying deathtrap”.
Well, that was yesterday, and I can say with certainty that that was the very last control room fire.
Absolute certainty?
Relative certainty. Actually, the entire console could do with an overhaul, but that’s for another day. One repair at a time. Speaking of which: hand me the ion bonder, would you?
The ion bonder?
FX: HE SNAPS HIS FINGERS REPEATEDLY.
Yes, come on, come on.
I don’t have it.
Oh!
I gave it to you, Doctor. Remember, when the console was on fire? You said you needed it to disable the chrono-compensator.
Oh yes, I did say that, didn’t I?
FX: HE PATS HIS POCKETS.
Well, I certainly don’t have it now. I wonder what I did with it?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 3: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: ADRIC ACTIVATES CONTROLS ON CONSOLE.
What’s this?
What’s what?
(PICKS UP DEVICE) This. It was lying on the console.
An ion bonder. The Doctor will need it if he’s repairing the internal dimension stabiliser.
FX: HE STOPS WORKING.
Look, perhaps we should do this another time — when we’re more likely to have the control room to ourselves.
Don’t chicken out now, Adric. I thought you could do this. — Maybe your sums aren’t as good as you make out. What did you really get that badge for?
Mathematical excellence!
I haven’t seen much excellence. The Alzarian curriculum must be a lot easier than the human one.
FX: ADRIC STARTS ACTIVATING CONTROLS AGAIN.
Earth, England, 1981, in the time you call Anno Domini.
Heathrow, don’t forget Heathrow.
Heathrow. Tegan, you know if you go back, there’1ll be a lot of people asking questions about what happened to your Aunt.
You honestly think that’s a good reason for not going back? Is that what you’d do in my position?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 8
Well, I’m not in your position, am I? I lost a family member, too, but I can’t go back home. Neither can Nyssa.
Well, I still have that option, and I want to exercise it. Are we on our way yet?
Not yet. It’s not as simple as it looks.
I hope the same’s true of you.
I’ve almost got it. The Doctor’s not a believer in pinpoint accuracy. But I think, if you take the time, you [can-]
FX: LOW RUMBLE, FOLLOWED BY WARNING ALARM BLEEPING ON CONSOLE.
Tell me that means you did everything right, I dare you.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 4: INT. TARDIS — CORRIDORS
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA WALK TOGETHER.

There used to be a meadow inside the TARDIS — there might still be, for all I know. It’d be a lovely spot for a few practice innings, cucumber sandwiches and a refreshing glass of ginger beer afterwards.
Assuming it didn’t get jettisoned along with the Zero Room.
Yes, assuming that.
We were fortunate not to be shot into the vortex, too.
Well, I believe there’s a fail-safe designed to prevent that from happening. It just it doesn’t appear to be working at the moment.
Another repair to add to the list.
At least the state of temporal grace is still functionin—
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISATION NOISE, OVERLY LOUD — JUDDERING LIKE
A NEEDLE ON A RECORD.
What’s that?
Nothing good! The control room, come on!
FX: THEY BREAK INTO A RUN.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 5: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: FAULTY MATERIALISATION NOISE CAN BE HEARD HERE ALSO, ALONG
WITH THE ALARM.
What’s happening?
That’s what I want to know! Are we going to explode?
Impossible! The TARDIS is indestructible! I think. (REACHES OUT — THEN CRIES OUT IN PAIN AS HE TOUCHES CONSOLE)
Can’t you do something? Don’t just stand there!
That’s all I can do! I’m stuck to the console!
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA RUN INTO ROOM.
This is just what I was afraid of!
Adric!
Doctor, help me!
Get away from the console!
I can’t!
You don’t know how to fly the TARDIS, and I do! Now don’t just stand there!
That’s all he can do, Doctor! He’s stuck fast to the console.
Doctor, help me!
Tegan, give me a hand!
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 11
No, don’t touch me!
He’s right! Whatever it is, it could affect you, too.
FX: ADRIC’S VOICE TAKES ON A DISTORTED, HOLLOW QUALITY.
(FX) I don’t know what went wrong! I was just trying to take
the TARDIS to Earth.
Look at him! He’s glowing!
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 6: INT. EXEMPLAR — BRIDGE
FX: PERSISTENT ENERGY PULSE, AT THE SAME RATE AS THE NOISE IN
THE TARDIS.
Your signal is breaking up! Your signal is breaking up! Say again — is all prepared?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 7: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: FAULTY MATERIALISATION NOISE, ALARM AND EFFECT ON ADRIC’S
VOICE PERSIST.
(FX) Prepared for what? Who’s saying that?
Nobody said anything. What’s he talking about?
I think the TARDIS is under some sort of psychic attack.
Is that possible?
Ordinarily, I would say not. But it appears to be happening, so, yes. Adric, everything’s going to be all right. Just trust me. You trust me, don’t you?
(FX) I don’t know what you mean. I’ve never heard of Zaltys!
He can’t hear you, Doctor.
Makes a change from just not listening. If we can get one of the panels off the base of the console, I might be able to... (STRAINS AS HE PULLS THE PANEL) .. do something.
FX: PANEL COMES LOOSE AND HITS THE FLOOR.
There!
Adric’s still glowing.
Yes, thank you, Tegan, that’s extremely helpful. Ah, here’s the trouble — someone deactivated the chrono-compensator. Schoolboy error.
You don’t need this, by any chance?
The ion bonder! So that’s where it got to!
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 14
It doesn’t matter, I need to do this manually.
FX: DOCTOR TINKERS WITH CONSOLE INNARDS.
(FX) Doctor? Doctor!
Nearly done, Adric.
FX: HIGH-PITCHED SHIMMERING.
He’s disappearing! Hurry, Doctor!
The best I can do is the best I can do, Tegan!
FX: MATERIALISATION NOISE STOPS.
(EMERGING FROM UNDER CONSOLE) There! A bit rough and ready, but it’ll do for the moment. Yet another repair to add to the list.
Doctor... you were too late.
What?
He’s gone. Adric’s gone.
Oh no.
Is Adric dead?
(UNSURE) I— (DETERMINED) No. No, not if I have anything to say about it. It should be possible to trace the attack back to its source.
You think someone kidnapped him?
I think someone wanted the pilot of a TARDIS. Adric just happened to be at the controls.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 15
You don’t know that for certain.

No, Tegan, I don’t! And if I don’t do this now, we’1ll never know! But if you’re intent on looking on the dark side, then consider this: what will Adric’s abductors do once they realise he doesn’t know a thing about the practicalities of time travel?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 8: INT. ZALTYS FACILITY — CORRIDOR
FX: SHIMMERING AS ADRIC MATERIALISES.
Doctor? Nyssa? Anyone here? Where is here?
FX: HE WANDERS AROUND, STOPS.
Not anywhere on the TARDIS — this is all grey metal and walkways. I’m lost. Typical! This is Tegan’s fault. She loves to get me into trouble!
FX: HE STARTS WALKING.
Hello? Can anyone hear me?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 9: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
Adric said something about ‘Zaltys’. Could that be a place or a person?
A planet, I think. The name rings a bell, but I don’t believe I’ve been there. Or if I have, then not recently. Not a particularly hospitable place, I think.
Then that must be where Adric is!
That’s where he might be. But even then, we don’t know the exact date or location.
(SARCASM) Great. So what do we do? Trust to luck?
It’s just possible I can fix the exact source of the incursion by using the TARDIS’ telepathic circuits. Tegan, I need absolute silence.
Why, is it dangerous?
No, I just always appreciate it when you’re quiet.
TUTS
Now, then...
FX: TELEPATHIC CIRCUITS ACTIVATE (AS HEARD IN FRONTIER IN
SPACE EPISODE 6).
(WHISPERS) I’m not sure he knows what he’s doing.
(WHISPERS) I wish I could say for certain either way. I know very little about telep— (MENTAL TWINGE) Ow!
(WHISPERS) Nyssa, what’s wrong?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 18
(WHISPERS) It’s nothing, just a headache. We mustn’t distract the Doctor.
Almost got it! I think.
FX: TELEPATHIC CIRCUITS CUT OUT.
Have you found him?
Well, I won’t know until I actually find him, will I?
FX: STARTS ACTIVATING CONTROLS. SAME EFFECT ON TEGAN’S VOICE
AS ON ADRIC’S EARLIER.
(FX) You don’t have to be so— What’s happening to me?
FX: SHIMMERING EFFECT.
Tegan!
Yes, I definitely haven’t forgotten about you, Tegan. You were the one who persuaded Adric to fly the TARDIS, weren’t you? Why can’t you trust me to— Tegan? Where’s she got to now?
She’s vanished, too. Just like Adric.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 10: INT. EXEMPLAR — CELL
FX: SHIMMERING AS TEGAN MATERIALISES.
(SHOCK OF FINDING HERSELF SOMEWHERE NEW) Ah! Where the..? — Can’t see where I am, it’s too dark. (CALLING OUT) Hello? Is anybody there? Doctor? Can anybody hear [me?]
FX: METAL WALL SLAMS DOWN.
(STARTLED) Whoa! What was that?
(D; OVER SPEAKER) A barrier just came down.
A barrier? Why?
(D) Simply a precautionary measure. Would you mind taking two steps to the left?
What?
(D) Two steps. To your left. Please.
FX: TEGAN TAKES TWO STEPS; ANOTHER BARRIER COMES DOWN.
(SHOCK) Ahh!
(D) Thank you. Forgive me, I simply wanted you on the right Side of the barrier.
Right for who — you or me?
(D) You simply appeared here without warning. In my position, would you act any differently?
Maybe not. Look, where are you? Why can’t I see you?
(D) What can you see?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 20
Nothing. I can’t see anything. So turn the lights on, why don’t you?
(D) I don’t need light to see you.
How convenient for you. — You’re not even in the same room as me, are you?
(D) I’m.. elsewhere.
I’ve had enough of this. (GROPING AROUND, FEELING WALLS) How do I get out of here...?
(D) Through the door, of course.
(DETERMINED) Right!
(D) But it’ll remain locked, until we’ve determined whether or not you pose any kind of threat to us.
Why would you think I’m a threat? I don’t even know who you are.
(D) You mentioned the Doctor.
No, I didn't. I just called out 'Doctor'. Look, who are you?
Tell me about him.
How do you know the Doctor?
(D) I’m asking you.
This is starting to sound less like a precautionary measure, more like an interrogation.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 21
(D) I promise you that after you’ve answered my questions, I’1l unlock the door for you.
Tell me where the door is first!
(D) Before you arrived here, you were on the TARDIS?
So you do know the Doctor!
(D) And we know you, too. Is the TARDIS coming here?
Too right it is! And that’s the last question I’m answering until you let me out of here.
(D) Then we have nothing more to talk about for the present.
FX: CLICK AS SPEAKER CUTS OUT.
Where’d you go? Hey! What have you done with Adric?
FX: SHE HAMMERS ON WALL.
Let me out of here!
FX: MORE HAMMERING.
I said, let me out!
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 11: EXT. ZALTYS SHORELINE
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISES. DOOR OPENS. DOCTOR AND NYSSA STEP OUT
ONTO PEBBLY SHORE. WATER LAPS AGAINST IT.
. Now, if either Adric or Tegan had been carrying a homing crystal, I might have been able to reverse-engineer its functions.
Unfortunately, neither of them had that foresight.
No. What do you think of our destination?
An orange beach under a purple sky — it’s making my eyes hurt.
It is rather garish. There are sunglasses in the TARDIS, if you want me to fetch you a pair?
No, Doctor. We need to start looking for Adric and Tegan.
Fair enough.
FX: HE SHUTS THE TARDIS DOOR.
Could this be Zaltys?
Possibly, although it does seem to match the descriptions I’ve been given of Thoros Beta. Which probably explains why I’ve avoided Thoros Beta so far.
Please tell me we don’t have an entire planet to search.

I’d hate to think Tegan’s pessimism is rubbing off on you, Nyssa. And while I can’t promise pin-point accuracy, I’m at least satisfied that we’re within a few miles of the source of the psychic attack. We might even find them with a telescope. Just give me a moment to pop back inside and get it. (TURNING BACK) I’1l grab the sunglasses while I’m [at it.]
FX: A DISTURBANCE IN THE WATER.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 23
Doctor, look! There’s something in the water!
Yes.. And it seems to be surfacing. Get behind me, Nyssa. I don’t mean to be an alarmist, but the last time something like this happened to me, it turned out to be—
FX: SABLE EMERGES FROM THE WATER.
A woman!
Ah. In that case, never mind.
FX: SABLE WALKS UP ONTO THE SHORE.
Hello, there. We come in peace. Er, can you hear me through that... apparatus?
(MUFFLED BENEATH HER HELMET) Is there any trace of contaminants?
Just had a check-up, as a matter of fact. Fighting fit.
(MUFFLED) I wasn’t talking to you.
(D; FAINT, OVER SABLE’S RADIO) Atmosphere’s clean. You could eat your dinner off it.
(MUFFLED) Thanks, Shaun. That’s all I wanted to know.
FX: HISS OF AIR, AS SABLE TWISTS AND REMOVES HER HELMET.
Hi.
Hello.
I'm Sable, the fellow on the other end of the line is Shaun.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 24
In that case, hello, Sable. And hello, Shaun, if you can hear me.
You two have names, I’m guessing.
Of course. This is Nyssa of Traken, and I’m the Doctor.
That’s not a name, it’s a title. I asked for your name.
Yes, it escapes me for the moment.
SCENE 12: INT. SABLE AND SHAUN’S SHIP (CONTINUOUS)
I can’t work out if he’s sincere or if he’s trying to be funny.
(D; OVER RADIO) You should see him in person. I never met anyone who wore vegetables like they were bling before.
(D) Forgive me for asking, Sable, but are you a native of this world?
(D) Whichever world that happens to be.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 13: EXT. ZALTYS SHORELINE (CONTINUOUS)
It’s just that your hair is such a vivid shade of pink it seems suited to our surroundings.
What, you don’t know where you are?
No, but we have our suspicions.
This is Zaltys. They call it the planet of the dead.
Do they? That’s funny, I’ve visited at least half a dozen planets of the dead. Whoever ‘they’ are, they don’t have much imagination when it comes to appellations.
All right, I call it the planet of the dead.
You never know, it might catch on.
Where is everyone, Sable?
Well, that’s the question, isn’t it? Where’d they all go?
(D) You’re not seeing any signs of life, then?
Only these two, Shaun, and they don’t seem to be locals. Even if one person buried everyone else, there’d be nobody left to bury him.
I take it you weren’t expecting to find anyone. Or anyone alive.
Let’s put it this way — I wasn’t expecting you.
(D) You know what I think.
I do know what you think.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 26
What who thinks? Shaun?
Shaun thinks you’re competitors.
I promise you we’re not. We don’t even know what it is we’re supposed to be competing for.
Indeed. If it’s anything to do with hair couture, we cheerfully admit defeat.
You're after the treasures of Zaltys.
Far from it. In fact, until you mentioned them, we weren’t aware Zaltys had any treasures.
We’re looking for our friends — a woman and a boy.
You haven’t seen them, I suppose?
They’re not under the water, if that’s what you mean. That’s just where my ship’s parked.
(D) Our ship.
Our ship. Best to try and keep a low profile.
Even when you’re not expecting to find anyone.
I found you, didn’t I?

She does have a point, Nyssa. Discretion is the better part of— Well, it’s the better part of a great many things, actually. But you seem to have your quest, and we have ours, so if you should happen to bump into our friends, would you mind pointing them in this direction?
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 27
Or we could search together.
That’s a generous offer, Sable, but I’m not sure our goals are necessarily compatible.
What if I insisted?
FX: SHE PRODUCES A GUN THAT HUMS AS IT POWERS UP.
It’s possible to insist without drawing a gun on us, you know.
Not in my neighbourhood. I don’t mistrust you, but I don’t exactly trust you either, so while I’m on Zaltys, I’m gonna be a lot happier if I know where you are.
Well, Doctor?
Well... Why not? Six eyes are better than four, I always say.
When do you ever say that?
Helped break the ice with a couple of Silurians once. Anyway, let’s just do as the nice lady with the weapon asks. Lead the way, Sable.
Just follow the direction of the barrel.
Of course.
FX: THEY START WALKING.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 14: INT. EXEMPLAR — CELL

Hey, you still there? I’m still here, in case you were wondering. Of course, you’re not wondering, because you locked me in. My eyes are adjusting to the dark a bit. Enough to have found that door you mentioned, so I’1l be going now..? Just say the word if you don’t want me to leave. (NO REPLY; TO SELF) Right then, time to find out what an “ion bonder” does. I just hope I’m pointing it in the right direction...
FX: ION BONDER ACTIVATES. A SMALL EXPLOSION.
Aah!
FX: DOOR SLIDES OPEN.
Done it! Now to find out where I an...
FX: SHE STEPS OUT OF THE CELL...
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 15: INT. EXEMPLAR — CORRIDOR (CONTINUOUS)
FX:  .. INTO THE CORRIDOR, AND WALKS CAUTIOUSLY OVER METAL
FLOORING.
The Doctor had better be around here somewhere. If he’s not looking for me, I’1ll be furious.
(D; OVER SPEAKER) From what I’ve heard of the Doctor, he’s unlikely to leave you to your own devices for long, Miss Grant.
Still there, are you? I thought I’d heard the back of you.
(D) You don’t mind if I use our cameras to keep an eye on you?
FX: TEGAN STUMBLES.
Ouch! Rabbits!
(D) Watch your step, Miss Grant.
I could do that if you’d just turn some lights on. And stop calling me Miss Grant!
(D) I beg your pardon. Do you prefer “Josephine” or simply a“ Jo” ?
I don’t prefer any of them because I’m not a Jo or a Josephine! My name’s Tegan Jovanka.
(D) I see.
Wish I could.
(D) I did think you weren’t a particularly close match for the
description. Taller...
FX: TEGAN TRIPS AGAIN.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 30
Ow!
(D) .. Slightly more co-ordinated. When my people first encountered the Doctor, he travelled with a human female. Forgive me for jumping to conclusions.
I’ll forgive you anything if you just send me back where I came from.
(D) I’m afraid that’s quite impossible, Tegan. Apparently, you arrived here quite by accident. Sending you back would undoubtedly please the Doctor — which I’m not in the business of doing.
You seem to think you’re his arch-enemy. Not called Zodin, are you?
(D) My name is Clarimonde.
Nope, he’s never mentioned you. Maybe you’re not as important as you reckon.
(D) We’ve not actually met. Those of my kind who encounter the Doctor tend not to live too long. So you’1l understand when I say that any friend of his is a foe of mine.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 16: EXT. ZALTYS FIELDS
FX: SABLE, THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA MARCH.
Seven months ago, all communications and signals from Zaltys just ceased.
Has the cause been ascertained?
No, but the natives were never the most sociable of people. You could count the number of them who’ve ever been off-planet on the fingers of one leg.
Now I come to think of it, I do seem to recall hearing something about an isolationist stance. But you’re not here because you’re concerned that next door haven’t been putting their empties out.
Once it was clear there was no getting through to anyone, the whole of Zaltys was placed under quarantine.
Quarantine? — Ah. The possibility of plague, perhaps. I see why people might jump to that conclusion.
Except for the distinct absence of bodies.
Some sort of tissue-eating bacteria, then? I saw something very Similar on Draconia two or three centuries ago.
Then why aren’t we affected?
Obviously, because there is no plague. Didn’t you hear Shaun say he hadn’t detected any contaminants?
Only after you’d come to the surface. Which indicates a rather cavalier attitude, if I might say so.
We couldn’t be sure until we’d breached the blockade and entered the atmosphere.
#223: ZALTYS by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 32
That still doesn’t explain what happened to the people of Zaltys.
Nyssa, was it? I’ve got to be honest with you, Nyssa, I’m not really interested in what happened to them. They’re either dead or they’re gone, either option is fine by me.
Because of the treasure you mentioned.
Not “treasure” singular — “treasures”. Technological, biological, mechanical.
You’re completely certain they have these things here?
Why else cut themselves off from the rest of the galaxy?
Perhaps they just didn’t care for the neighbours. It seems to me you’re risking a lot on wishful thinking.
Other scavengers have made bigger scores on flimsier hunches.
You’re a scavenger, then. I thought I recognised the look.
